segments.text: When it comes to reading, to portray their reading methods, I should write at the beginning, read the book from the very start.
I was going to leave in the middle of the second hand, and I could go on with this book, and I was going to very faithfully carry on to the end.
About seven years ago, I started this book called The Israel Reading.
It started as a little essay.
There seemed to be several views that met there.

And with the question, I was very intrigued as to why the history of what I love, the history of literature, had always been written from the point of view of the writers, when in fact, it seemed to me, it was the readers who decided what a book is going to be.
Jonathan Swift adamantly thought that his book was fierce political satire, and I believe the readers put the book on the shelf of children's books.
The powers of the reader, I think, have not been chronicled in any systematic way.
And when I worked on this book, I realized why.
Probably because to write even a history of reading, a big history of reading, as I first arrogantly thought I would be able to do, is to write the history of the world.
It's an extremely complex activity and I found that
To describing the chronology of literature, the usual chronology of what we call history is quite useful because things happen in a different order for readers.

It was interesting to discover that, for instance, we readers used to read aloud for the longest time, but the natural way of reading, then we picked up on this with trying to understand a text that seems complex, is to read aloud.
silent being did not become common, at least in the Western world until the 10th century.
And in my explorations of the history of being, I came across a wonderful moment in the confessions of St.
Augustine with St.
Augustine, a teacher in Milan.
He had left, he had come from North Africa, come to Rome and try to set up a little school in Rome.
the students for premiums and nobody paid.
By the time they came to pay their rent and they all disappeared.
So he decided to try to get back in Milan.
And in Milan he went to visit one of his mother's acquaintances, Saint Ambrose.
And he comes upon Ambrose in his cell surrounded with books
And obviously doing something that Augustine identifies as reading, which he can't believe is reading because those towns are coming down to found books as far as.
So we have, just like time, a description of how surprising it was to discover a solid reading at that time.
Many of these anecdotes, these hidden readers came about as, as I will explain, as history of reading.
I loved Lin Tarrant-Words' book because it reflected one of those aspects.
A Canadian essay, Stanley Percy, told me once that for readers there must be a million autobiographies because
We recognize ourselves in the experience that others have written about.
And Sharon Schwartz's book seems to me an encapsulated version of all those readings.

and Martin and so on.

He was studying Anglo-Saxon at the time.

An aspect that I explored in the history of reading was the privacy of reading.
How extraordinary the fact that we can establish this activity without anyone else knowing what takes place.
The rise of silent reading has something to do with this intense privacy.
It is extraordinary how many of the great heresies in the Christian church rise at the time where silent reading becomes pervasive.
There is also a prophylactic aspect
to reading.
Diderot in the 18th century would cure his wife who would suffer from depression.
She was a strongly bigoted woman who you would not imagine as the wife of
very liberal and racy Diderot.
So Diderot would cure her by reading passages from racy Spanish and French novels and he invented this
prescription order of two cases of Chicago and one case between and so on.
And it seems that it's an use here in Armand's ear, did cure her from Verdepressant.
Of course, in the extraordinary role of microbiology in which patients, the nurse also works with the same system, trying to
fewer patients through reading.
But perhaps the aspect that interests me most about reading, the one that made me banish this sense of how was the pleasure of being subversive.
Oliver said that poetry makes nothing happen, and it's true that
a book is there until we read it, until we make something out of it.
And I think across so many cases where readers are able to
turn the book into an extraordinary subversive force.

And at the end of the play, you remember, where the hero who refuses to become a rhinoceros
shouts out, I will not capitulate.

Finally, that same subversive power is, I think, sometimes best read by those who fear it.
I think censors
are extraordinary subtle readers.

A question that comes up over time now is
whether reading will continue.
George Steiner has said that perhaps we will have reading houses in the future where those quaint enough to read would go to pursue their activity.
But I'm not convinced, you know, I'm not in this immagized mode, or it seems that books will disappear, that people don't read it.
I mean, you are true that that is not the case.
More books have published than ever before.

And also, if I look back at my school, if I look back at my classes at elementary school, high school, and so on, yeah, there were four or five, maybe six or ten friends of mine who I remember were teen readers, but that's about teens.
Most of the class were not keen readers.
They hated the English or Spanish literature class, and they never went to the library and looked at the same thing before.
I'm not afraid of what is called the encroaching technology.
I certainly don't share St.
Burkhardt and Gutenberg energies as this kind of end of the millennium apocalyptic language that were all going to be destroyed by computers and so on.

If we could not wish for a conclusion, if we could allow
this technology to open up new ways of reading for us of going back to methods that have always been there, their interactive text that existed and so on.
The participation of the reader that existed from the very first writer who put that view on a page speaking to me, the general reader.
If we could allow these things and read, perhaps, in a less assertive way, in a vaguely more ambiguous way, a richer way, then perhaps we will continue to cherish this craft of ours.
